utterances: For a look at possible implications of this health care standoff I'm joined by E.J.
Dionne of The Washington Post and Brookings Institution, and Reihan Salam, a blogger at National Review and a fellow at the New America Foundation.
Welcome to both of you.
Mr.
E.J.
DIONNE (Columnist, The Washington Post; Senior Fellow, Brookings Institution): Thank you.
Good to be with you.
Thanks for having us.
Reihan, I'm going to start with you.
The White House this week was talking like this was the health care home stretch, the final stretch.
President Obama said he'd do everything in his power to get this done.
Can the Republicans stop him?
I think that the Republicans aren't going to stop him.
But it can be stopped by some reluctant Democrats.
There might be about six of those Democrats who voted against the House health bill the first time around who could be persuaded.

But among that larger group of House Democrats who voted against it there are lots of them who still have serious reservations and lots of them who have real political liabilities that would make it very hard for them to go along with the health reform push right now.
E.J.
is the president sensitive enough to those liabilities that those Democrats face?
I think he's sensitive but I think he's making a right call.
I think passing the health care bill helps the party far, far more than it hurts the party, which is why I think it's going to pass.
It shows they can govern after a messy year in which people began to doubt that.
And some have said Obama is not tough enough, not enough of like L.B.J.
was in pushing through his program.

I think he is helping himself and his party by finally going on the offensive, answering the Republicans and saying clearly, there are some things and some causes I'll fight for and affordable health care is one of them.
In answering the Republicans he did, as we said, reach out and embrace some of the proposals that they had put forth.
However, John Boehner said you can't add a couple of Republican sprinkles on top of a 2700-page bill and call it bipartisan.
Is there anything more he can or should do?
No, I don't think there's a thing he can do to get Republicans right now.
The health care bill already, even before Obama put his sprinkles on, to use Mr. Boehner's metaphor, already had a lot of other Republican ideas.
This bill looks most like a bill put forward by former Senator John Chafee, the late Senator John Chafee, a moderate Republican back in the mid '90s.
This is a market-oriented bill.
You can't get more Republican than this bill is without becoming a Republican.
Reihan, do you agree with that?
Because many Republicans say that he is not doing enough to inject free market principals into this proposal.
I actually don't agree with that.
And I think it is certainly true that there were some moderate Republicans who backed similar proposal a while ago but, of course, we've learned quite a lot since then.
One of the things we've learned is that the so called doc fix, the sustainable growth rate part of Medicare is actually very, very expensive.
It's very expensive to fix.
And in the past we've offset that and this time around we're not offsetting it.
And that creates lots of big unaccounted for costs that a lot of Republicans and Democrats, I might add, are very concerned about.

And so, I think that there are a lot of Republicans and, again, lots of Democrats who are worried about creating a new health entitlement, when we have a variety of other entitlements that we've had a very hard time restraining.
So, there are some good aspects to this bill but there are some ones that are causing a lot of consternation, as well, not just among conservatives.
If there was a hall of fame for budget directors, then Jack Lew surely would have earned a place for his service in that role under President Clinton.
Oh, I was thinking second.
What I wanted to do is I wanted to take those types of songs and bring them to a generation that never heard them.
When we did this song, Dottie wasn't even supposed to do the song with me.
I called her up out of the audience and she's just quintessential Dottie.
My whole prayer was, `Lord, let us be able to grab ahold of this night and let it be felt by everybody that hears this.
...(Unintelligible).
Now truly you--and you feel it, as I said.

I want to talk to you about why you decided to open up your life so much to fans and others, but before I do that, I want to ask you the same question I asked of Yolanda Adams when she was here not long ago.
When I think of great songs of contemporary gospel, when I think of ""We Fall Down,"" that, 20 years from now, is going to go on that list of classics.
Yeah.
The fact that you have been able to create something like that, a true modern-day masterpiece, do you think about that at all?
No.
If you get caught up in that, then you get also caught up in the attempt to reproduce that.
'Cause everybody's always asking, `Oh, we need another this.
The record company, `We need another ""We Fall Down,"" we need another ""Stand,"" we need another ""Speak To My Heart.""' They didn't come through contrived machinations.
I didn't sit down and, you know, conjure up.
It was just something that flowed.
(Soundbite of song ""We Fall Down"")
(Singing) We fall down, but we get up, oh, yes, for our savior is just a sinner who fell down.
(Soundbite of song ""Speak To My Heart"")
(Singing) Oh, speak to my heart, Holy Spirit.
Give me the words that will bring new light.
(Soundbite of song ""Stand"")
(Singing) But after you've done all you can, you just stand.
I didn't think those three songs were going to do anything at all.
Really?
Stand,"" ""We Fall Down"" and ""Speak To My Heart,"" those were songs that were just filler songs.
Really?
I thought other songs on the CD was going to be the hit song.
You know what's interesting?
I was saving ""Stand"" for a different question because, for me, the first time I heard it was not your rendition, but BeBe Winans' rendition.
Yeah.
And I recall literally feeling--I was down at the time, honestly, and I could lift my chest and my back and my shoulders from that song.
Yeah.
You have to know, though, Donnie, that there are times that your gift does touch people in that way.
Yeah.
I realize it after the fact, you know, 'cause I get tunnel vision.
Stand,"" that song was--before BeBe did it was out many years before that.
And BeBe is the one that brought it to Oprah.
That's how everybody would start hearing ""Stand.
(Soundbite of ""Stand"")
(Singing) You just stand.
I'd never met Oprah and when BeBe sang it, they cried at a sunrise service.
And so Oprah came and said, `BeBe, that's a great song you wrote.
And BeBe said, `I didn't write this song.
He said, `You really think this song is something, then you need to hear Donnie McCurklin.
He never says my name right.
And for BeBe to do that alone, that's the first miracle.
That's right.
That BeBe...
For those of us who know that boy, that's right.
BeBe doesn't say thank you and walk away, that was the first miracle.
We're saying that in love, BeBe Winans.
I love you, BeBe.
You know, but BeBe hit me and said, `Donnie, whatever you do right now, send Oprah the thing, the song.
We sent Oprah the song.
I was in the Bahamas, and my telephone rang and I heard, you know, stanzas blasted.
And my publisher called and said, `Oprah's about to call you.'
(Soundbite of song ""Stand"")
(Singing) ...through the storm...
(Singing) Stand.
(Singing) ...stand through the rain...
(Singing) Stand.
